content.text: Define _gravitational potential_ at a point
Use your answer in **(i)** to explain why the gravitational potential near an isolated mass is always negative
show that its orbital speed is \(7.4 \times 10^{3} \text{m s}^{-1}\)
calculate its gravitational potential energy
energy =   .........  J
A spherical planet has mass \(6.00 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\) and radius \(6.40 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\)
The planet may be assumed to be isolated in space with its mass concentrated at its centre
A satellite of mass \(340 \text{kg}\) is in a circular orbit about the planet at a height \(9.00 \times 10^{5} \text{m}\) above its surface
For the satellite:
Rockets on the satellite are fired for a short time. The satellite's orbit is now closer to the surface of the planet
State and explain the change, if any, in the kinetic energy of the satellite
an ideal gas
the symbol \(\langle c^2 \rangle\)
State what is meant by:
Assuming the gas acts like an ideal gas, show that the number of atoms of gas in the cylinder is \(3.0 \times 10^{23}\)
Each atom of the gas, assumed to be a sphere, has a radius of \(3.2 \times 10^{-11} \text{m}\)
Use the answer in (i) to estimate the actual volume occupied by the gas atoms
One of the assumptions of the kinetic theory of gases is related to the volume of the atoms
State this assumption. Explain whether your answer in **(ii)** is consistent with this assumption

A cylinder contains a fixed mass of a gas at a temperature of \(120^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The gas has a volume of \(6.8 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) at a pressure \(2.4 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~Pa}\)
The pressure \(p\) of an ideal gas having density \(\rho\) is given by the expression

where \(x\) is the vertical displacement of the tube from its equilibrium position

For a tube having cross-sectional area \(A\) of \(4.5 \text{cm}^2\) and a total mass \(M\) of \(0.17 \text{kg}\), the period of oscillation of the tube is \(1.3 \text{s}\)

The tube floats upright in a liquid of density \(\rho\), as illustrated in Fig. 3.1
The tube is pushed a short distance into the liquid and then released
State three features of the orbit of a geostationary satellite
A signal is transmitted from Earth to a geostationary satellite. Initially, the signal has power \(3.2 \text{kW}\). The signal is attenuated by \(194 \text{dB}\)
Calculate the signal power received by the satellite
Suggest one advantage and one disadvantage of the use of geostationary satellites compared with polar-orbiting satellites for communication between points on the Earth's surface
advantage:
disadvantage:
State what is meant by an _electric field_
An isolated solid metal sphere has radius \(R\). The charge on the sphere is \(+Q\) and the electric field strength at its surface is \(E\)
On Fig. 5.1, draw a line to show the variation of the electric field strength with distance \(x\) from the centre of the solid sphere for values of \(x\) from \(x = 0\) to \(x = 3R\)
The sphere in **(b)** has radius \(R = 0.26 \text{m}\)
Electrical breakdown (a spark) occurs when the electric field strength at the surface of the sphere exceeds \(2.0 \times 10^{6} \text{V} \text{m}^{-1}\)
Determine the maximum charge that can be stored on the sphere before electrical breakdown occurs
Define the capacitance of a parallel-plate capacitor

Draw labelled circuit diagrams, one in each case, to show how the three capacitors may be connected to give a total capacitance of:
